questions.text: Which of the following is an advantage of the procedure shown in the image over its midline counterpart?

choices.text: Lesser chance of anal sphincter involvement

questions.solution:
The above image shows mediolateral episiotomy. The primary advantage of mediolateral episiotomy over midline episiotomy is that there is a lesser chance of anal sphincter involvement due to extension. 

An episiotomy is an intended incision of the perineum with the goal of enlargement of the vaginal opening for birth. Prior to episiotomy, analgesia is provided by existing labor regional analgesia, bilateral pudendal nerve block, or local infiltration with 1% lignocaine. Typically, an episiotomy is completed when the head is visible during a contraction to a diameter of 4 to 5 cm.

Midline episiotomy begins at the fourchette, incises the perineal body in the midline, and ends well before the external anal sphincter. Mediolateral episiotomy begins at the midline of the fourchette and is directed to the right or left at an angle of 60 degrees off the midline. This angle accounts for the stretch distortion of the perineal anatomy during crowning. After delivery and resolution of the distortion, it ultimately yields an incision 45 degrees from the midline for suturing.

Midline episiotomy Mediolateral episiotomy
Surgical repair is easy Surgical repair is difficult
Blood loss is less Blood loss is more
Healing is superior Healing is not so good
Dyspareunia is rare Dyspareunia is comparatively more

Postoperative pain is less

Postoperative pain is more

Extension, if occurs, may involve the anal sphincter

Extension, even if it occurs, will not involve the anal sphincter

 

Related Pearl: Mediolateral Episiotomy

It begins within 3 mm of the midline in the posterior fourchette and is directed laterally at an angle of at least 60 degrees from the midline. This yields an incision of 45 degrees off the midline.

It is essentially an inflicted second-degree perineal tear.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
  • Fascia covering those muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

Advantage: Lesser risk of anal sphincter laceration, hence it is preferred over median episiotomy.

Disadvantage: Increased blood loss and causes more perineal pain and dyspareunia.

questions.text:
Arrange the following steps of nasogastric tube insertion in the correct order.
  1. Inject 10 mL of air through the tube while auscultating the left upper quadrant of the abdomen.
  2. Gently insert the nasogastric tube into the nostril, at 90 degree angle to the long axis of the head.
  3. Ask the patient to sit upright and flex the neck forward.
  4. Ask the patient to take small sips of water and swallow.
  5. Tape the tube in place.
questions.solution:
The correct order of steps in the process of insertion of a nasogastric (NG) tube is:

  1. Lubricate the first 2 to 3 inches of the tube with lignocaine jelly lubricant.
  2. Have the patient flex the neck forward, bringing his/her chin towards the chest.
  3. Slowly and gently begin inserting the tube into the nostril straight back at a 90-degree angle to the long axis of the head.
  4. Have the patient begin taking small sips of water through a straw and swallow as you gently advance the tube. Timing the advancement of the tube in conjunction with the patient swallowing greatly facilitates the passage of the NG tube into the stomach. 
  5. Check the position of the tube by:
    • Injecting 10 mL air through the tube and listening to the left upper quadrant for a rush of the air.
    • Obtaining radiographs: radiography is the gold standard for determining the correct placement of NG tubes.
  6. Tape the tube in place. 

Indications for NG tube include:

  • Gastrointestinal lavage or aspiration in patients with suspected or known overdose
  • Gastric decompression in cases of gastric outlet obstruction, intestinal obstruction and paralytic ileus.
  • Zollinger-Ellison syndrome is characterized by hypersecretion of gastrin resulting in acid-induced diarrhoea that is controlled by nasogastric aspiration of gastric secretions
  • Nutritional support and administration of medications via GI route

Contraindications for NG tube include:

  • Significant facial trauma or basilar skull fracture
  • Esophageal burns or caustic ingestion
  • Recent surgery on esophagus or stomach
  • Esophageal stricture or atresia

questions.text: Identify the procedure shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the given image is lacrimal sac syringing or irrigation. It is done to check the patency of the lacrimal drainage system. 

Lacrimal sac syringing should be performed only after ascertaining punctal patency. If there is severe stenosis, surgical enlargement of the punctum may be required before canalicular and naso-lacrimal duct patency can be confirmed. This procedure is contraindicated in the presence of an acute infection. 

The procedure begins with the instillation of local anesthetic in the conjunctival sac. A punctum dilator is used to enlarge the punctal orifice. A lacrimal cannula on a saline-filled syringe is inserted into the lower punctum and, whilst keeping a gentle stretch laterally on the eyelid, advanced a few millimeters, following the contour of the canaliculus. A hard stop occurs if the cannula enters the lacrimal sac, coming to a stop at the medial wall of the sac. The rigid lacrimal bone can be felt through the medial wall. This excludes complete obstruction of the canalicular system. Gentle saline irrigation is then tried. If saline passes into the nose and throat, it will be tasted by the patient. This indicates the presence of a patent lacrimal system. A patient can still have watering of the eye due to subtle lacrimal pump failure or stenosis. Failure of saline to reach the throat is indicative of total obstruction of the nasolacrimal duct. In this situation, the lacrimal sac will distend slightly during irrigation and there will be reflux of the saline through the opposite punctum.

Findings on syringing Diagnosis
Unable to pass cannula Punctal occlusion
Regurgitation through same punctum but good flow through the other punctum Upper/Lower canaliculus block
Regurgitation through opposite punctum Common canalicular block
Regurgitation through opposite punctum after a few minutes of flow; pressure syringing leads to flow Partial nasolacrimal duct block
Early regurgitation through opposite punctum Complete nasolacrimal duct block

questions.text: A senior resident working in an intensive care unit has assembled the following equipment to perform a procedure. Which of the following procedures he would be performing?
questions.solution:
From the materials which have been gathered by the senior resident, it can be inferred that he would be performing a central venous catheterization.

The image below shows the equipment for performing a central venous catheterization.

The instruments are numbered as follows:

  1. A syringe with a local anesthetic
  2. Scalpel in case venous cutdown is needed
  3. Introducer needle on the syringe with saline to detect backflow of blood upon vein penetration
  4. Guidewire
  5. Tissue dilator
  6. An indwelling catheter
  7. Additional fasteners, and corresponding surgical thread

The catheter can be inserted into any of the following veins - Right and internal jugular veins, subclavian vein, external jugular veins, and femoral vein.

Indications of central venous catheterization include

  • Central venous pressure monitoring
  • Pulmonary artery catheterization and monitoring
  • Transvenous cardiac pacing
  • Temporary hemodialysis
  • Drug administration (concentrating vasoactive drugs, hyperalimentation, chemotherapy, agents irritating peripheral veins, prolonged antibiotic therapy)
  • Rapid infusion of fluids
  • Aspiration of air emboli
  • Inadequate peripheral venous access
  • Sampling site for repeated blood testing

Complications of central vein catheterization are

  • Arterial puncture - This is the most common mechanical complication. 
  • Cardiac tamponade - This is the most important life-threatening complication. It occurs as a result of puncture of intrapericardial superior vena cava, right atrium, or right ventricle.
  • Pneumothorax - This is more common in subclavian vein catheterization as a result of injury to the underlying pleura.
  • Chylothorax - This can occur particularly in left subclavian vein catheterization. But it is not the most common.
  • Injury to the associated nerves - like brachial plexus, stellate ganglion, phrenic nerve, or vocal cords.
  • Thromboembolism - This can lead to venous thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. It is more common with femoral veins.
  • Infections - most common late complication.

The image below shows central venous catheterization

questions.text: Identify the injection technique in the given image.
questions.solution:
The technique shown in the given image is intradermal injection.

An intradermal injection is usually given on the ventral part of the forearm, around 10 cm from the antecubital crease. The preparation of the site is done with an alcohol pad, beginning at the center and moving outward in a circular motion. Then the patient's forearm is held and the skin gently stretched with the thumb. The needle is inserted, bevel up, at a 15-degree angle into the upper layers of the skin. On injecting, a small wheal or bleb will form. This signals proper intradermal placement. The needle should be withdrawn at the same 15-degree angle. The wheal or bleb will disappear gradually and should not be rubbed.

questions.text: A primigravida presents to the labor room with adequate uterine contractions. The presenting part of the baby is two buttocks and the external genitalia as shown in the image below. Which of the following maneuver is used to deliver the extended legs of this baby?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image in which the presenting part is two buttocks and external genitalia are suggestive of a frank breech presentation. Pinard maneuver is used to deliver the extended legs in this presentation.

In frank breech presentation, thighs are flexed on the trunk, and legs are extended at the knees. The presenting part would be two buttocks and external genitalia. This maneuver will facilitate delivery of the legs, only after the fetal umbilicus has been reached.

The patient should be under general anesthesia. The palmar surface of the obstetrician is to be introduced facing the ventral surface of the fetus. The breech is pushed up at least to the level of the symphysis pubis. 

Middle and index fingers should apply pressure in the popliteal fossa and cause partial leg flexion. The head is flexed by the other hand abdominally i.e. externally. The foot is brought down by grasping at the ankle with internal fingers. The other leg is brought down in the same manner.

The image below shows Pinard’s maneuver:

 Breech presentation can be divided into the following:

  • Frank breech: Breech with flexion at hip joints, extension at knee joints.
  • Complete breech: Breech with flexion at both hip joints, one or both knees at flexed.
  • Incomplete breech: Breech with extension at one or both hips, as a result, one or both feet or knees lie below the breech. Footling is a type of incomplete breech with one or both feet below the breech.

 

Other options: 

Ritgen maneuver:

Used in the assisted delivery of the head by extension in normal labor. If the expulsive efforts are inadequate, the Ritgen maneuver is employed for assisted delivery of the head. This is accomplished by pushing the chin upward with the fingers of the right hand (positioned over the anococcygeal region) while the left hand exerts pressure on the occiput. Hence, the head is delivered by extension. 

 

Lovset maneuver: It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

 

Burns Marshall method: It is used in the delivery of the after-coming head in breech presentation.

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: A 32-year-old fisherman presented to the clinic with complaints of pain and swelling over the left middle finger for 2 days as shown in the image given below. Tenderness is elicited over the affected nail on examination. Which of the following statements is incorrect about the management of this condition?

choices.text: Incision is made on the hyponychium
Best treated with incision, drainage and appropriate antibiotics
Digital block is given using lignocaine without adrenaline

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with the image showing erythema and swelling around the nail folds is suggestive of acute paronychia with abscess formation. Incision and drainage needs to be done in this case, and the incision is made on the eponychium. 

Acute paronychia refers to the infection of the nail bed. It often occurs following minor trauma and is caused by Staphylococcus aureus. It presents as a painful red swelling of the area lateral to the nail. After the initial inflammation, pus accumulates beside and sometimes under the nail. A digital pressure test is used to assess if an abscess is present or not. Pressure is applied to the volar aspect of the involved digit. A larger than expected area of blanching will be visible at the paronychia if an abscess is present and drainage will be needed. 

Acute paronychia is best treated with incision, drainage and appropriate antibiotic therapy. Incision and drainage is usually done by giving a digital block using lignocaine without adrenaline, since digits have an end arterial supply. Occasionally, nail removal may also be done to allow full drainage of the pus collection.

questions.text: Which of the following is the site of placement of the V2 chest lead while recording an ECG?

choices.text: In the fourth intercostal space just to the left of the sternum
In the fifth intercostal space just to the left of the sternum
At the anterior axillary line in the fifth intercostal space
At the midclavicular line in the fifth intercostal space

questions.solution:
While recording an ECG, the V2 chest lead is placed at the 4th intercostal space, to the left of the sternum 

The site of placement of the chest leads is as follows:

V1: 4th intercostal space, right of the sternum 
V2: 4th intercostal space, left of the sternum 
V3: 5th intercostal space, left of the sternum (Option B)
V4: 5th intercostal space, centered on clavicle(Option D)
V5: 5th intercostal space, left of V4
V6: 5th intercostal space, under the left arm

An ECG can be recorded by using an active electrode that is connected to an electrode at zero potential (unipolar recording) or by using two active electrodes (bipolar recording).

For unipolar recording, six chest leads or precordial leads (V1–V6) and three limb leads (VR-right arm, VL-left arm, and VF-left foot) are used. Because the heart surfaces are close to the chest wall, the chest lead mainly records the electrical potential of the cardiac musculature immediately beneath it. Therefore, relatively minute abnormalities in the heart muscles can cause marked changes in the ECGs recorded from individual chest leads.

In some patients, posterior leads may be placed on the same horizontal plane as V4 to facilitate the detection of acute posterolateral infarction (V7 in midaxillary line; V8 in posterior axillary line; and V9 in posterior scapular line).

Right chest leads (V3R and V6R) can help enhance the detection of right ventricular involvement in patients with inferior infarction.

Related Pearl: ECG Leads

LA – Left arm: RA – Right arm: LL – Left leg: LF – Left foot

  • Limb leads measure the electrical activity in the frontal plane
  • Chest leads measure the electrical activity in the horizontal plane


Limb Lead Location Augmented limb leads Location Chest leads Location

questions.text: A patient presents with breathlessness and low-grade fever for the last 2 weeks. Her chest radiograph is given below. Choose the correct statement regarding the management of this patient.

choices.text: 2 litres of fluid may be withdrawn in one go
Usual approach is from the anterior aspect
Entry site for the needle should be on the inferior aspect of the rib
ADA measurement in the sample is indicated

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the X-ray are suggestive of pleural effusion, most likely due to tuberculosis. The next step for this patient will be to perform a thoracocentesis and send the sample for analysis. For tuberculosis, adenosine deaminase (ADA) analysis of the pleural fluid is recommended. 

In any patient diagnosed with a pleural effusion, an effort should be made to find the cause. This requires a diagnostic thoracocentesis and analysis of the pleural fluid in terms of whether it is a transudate or an exudate based on Light's criteria:

  1. Pleural fluid protein/serum protein >0.5
  2. Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH >0.6
  3. Pleural fluid LDH more than two-thirds the upper limit of normal for serum

If the pleural fluid meets one of these criteria, it is considered exudative pleural effusion. Sometimes, special investigations like ADA and cytology might be required to rule out tuberculosis and malignancy respectively.

For thoracocentesis, a posterior approach (option B) is preferred. The patient should sit on the edge of the bed, leaning forward with the arms abducted onto a pillow on a bedside stand. The patient might have severe dyspnea, so it is important to assess whether they can maintain this position for 10 minutes before performing the procedure. The entry site for the thoracocentesis is at the superior aspect of the rib (option C). This prevents any injury to the intercostal nerve and vessels. 

While maintaining gentle negative pressure, the needle should be slowly advanced into the pleural space. If a diagnostic tap is being performed, 30-50 mL of fluid will be adequate. If a therapeutic thoracocentesis is being performed, a maximum of 1 liter of pleural fluid should be withdrawn at a given time (option A). Withdrawal of quantities more than this can cause re-expansion pulmonary edema. A chest radiograph should be obtained post-procedure to evaluate for a pneumothorax. The patient should be instructed to inform the doctors if new shortness of breath develops. 

Related Pearl: Types of pleural effusion

Transudative Pleural effusion

  • Congestive heart failure (most common)
  • Cirrhosis
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Myxedema 
  • Peritoneal dialysis
  • Urinothorax
  • Hypoalbuminemia
  • Constrictive pericarditis
  • Superior vena cava obstruction

Exudative Pleural effusion 

  • Infections: Tuberculosis, pneumonia, intraabdominal abscess (like- liver abscess)
  • Malignancy: Pleural mesothelioma, metastasis, lymphoma
  • Connective tissue diseases: SLE, rheumatoid arthritis
  • Drugs: Amiodarone, bromocriptine, dantrolene, dasatinib, methysergide, nitrofurantoin
  • Others:
    • Pancreatitis
    • Asbestosis
    • Pulmonary embolism
    • Hemothorax
    • Chylothorax
    • Meigs' syndrome 
    • Dressler syndrome (post-myocardial infarction or cardiac surgery)
    • Yellow nail syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the procedure performed with the given instrument?

choices.text: Used during injection sclerotherapy for hemorrhoids
Can be done without prior digital rectal examination
Can be done in a patient with acute anal fissure
Lower part of sigmoid colon can be visualised

questions.solution:
The given image shows a proctoscope, used for performing proctoscopy. One of the therapeutic indications of proctoscopy is performing injection sclerotherapy of hemorrhoids.

Proctoscopy can be used to inspect the anus, anorectal junction and the lower part of the rectum (option D). Most commonly the patient is examined in the left lateral (Sims) position with the buttocks overlying the edge of the examination couch. Alternatively in younger patients, prone jack-knife or knee-elbow positions may be used. A digital rectal examination is mandatory before performing a proctoscopy (option B). Minor procedures such as injection sclerotherapy or banding of hemorrhoids and biopsy of suspected neoplasms can also be carried out in conjunction with proctoscopy (option A). Acute anal fissure is a contraindication for doing proctoscopy (option C) because it is extremely painful for the patient.

questions.text: Which of the following techniques would you not follow while performing direct laryngoscopy?

choices.text: The force for lifting the blade is achieved by radial flexion of wrist.
The blade is inserted into right side of the mouth.
The laryngoscope is lifted at a 45-degree angle
The procedure is performed in sniffing position.

questions.solution:
While performing direct laryngoscopy, the force for lifting the blade is achieved by the anterior deltoid and triceps, not by radial flexion of the wrist.

Direct laryngoscopy is the technique used for tracheal intubation which involves direct visualization of the glottis with the assistance of a laryngoscope. 

The procedure is performed in the sniffing position. It involves approximately 35 degrees of cervical flexion. During the procedure, the blade is inserted on the right side of the mouth, and the flange is used to sweep the tongue to the left. (Option B). The base of the tongue is approached and the blade is lifted forward at a 45-degree angle(Option C).

Once a complete view of the glottis is achieved, the endotracheal tube is grasped with the right hand and guided through the vocal cords into the trachea. Damage to upper incisors can occur when the tip of the blade should is lifted by using the laryngoscope as a lever.

The procedure is performed by using a laryngoscope. It is an instrument used for the examination of the larynx and the facilitation of tracheal intubation. It has three components: the handle, the blade, and the light source. The Macintosh and Miller blades are the most popularly used blades.

Miller's blade is a straight blade that is inserted using the para-glossal technique. This technique avoids contact with the maxillary incisors and provides maximal tongue control.

It is used in:

  • Neonates, infants, and young children
  • Adults with short thyromental distance and long floppy epiglottis.

A Macintosh blade is a sharply curved blade with a large flange. The advantages of a curved blade include:

  • Greater room available for the passage of an endotracheal tube
  • Less damage to the teeth

questions.text: You are doing urinary bladder catheterization for a patient. Till what point will you insert the Foley catheter before inflating the bulb?

choices.text: Bulb should be inflated as soon as urine begins to flow

questions.solution:
The bulb of the Foley catheter should be inflated once the catheter has been inserted almost to the hub. This ensures that the balloon is not inflated in the prostate, bladder neck, or urethra. The flow of urine alone may not be the surest sign that the tip of the Foley has reached the urinary bladder, since it can appear even at the level of the bladder neck.

Once the balloon is inflated, pull the Foley catheter out gently until it stops. The Foley catheter is now in the proper position. Make sure the drainage bag is properly attached and tape the Foley catheter to the abdomen. Bacitracin ointment is applied to the urethral meatus one to three times per day to prevent irritation from the catheter and urinary tract infection. If the patient is uncircumcised, the foreskin will need to be placed back into its original position. 

Related Pearl: Foley's Catheter

A Foley catheter is a thin, sterile tube inserted into the bladder to drain urine. Because it can be left in place in the bladder for a period of time, it is also called an indwelling catheter.

French scale corresponds to the outer diameter in millimetres, and 1Fr is 0.3 mm in diameter.

Fr. size = 3 x d, where d is the outer diameter in mm. 

A 18 Fr. catheter will have a circumference of approximately 18 mm and a diameter of 6 mm.

questions.text:
You are a newly posted intern in the department of surgery. During your routine ward rounds, you notice a patient with an ulcer being treated with the following therapy. Which of the following statements are true regarding this modality of treatment?
  1. The therapy involves the application of continuous pressure of -250 mm of Hg
  2. It increases blood flow and decreases wound edema
  3. It creates a suitable bed for a flap or graft cover
  4. It consists of an airtight and sealed wound drain covered with an opaque adhesive film
  5. Everyday redressing of the wound is not required with this therapy
questions.solution:
The image above shows the vacuum-assisted closure of an ulcer. The true statements regarding VAC are 2, 3, and 5.

VAC therapy is also called negative pressure wound closure. It creates an intermittent (not continuous) negative pressure of -125 mm Hg to promote the formation of healthy granulation tissue.

It is made up of foam with a perforated wound drain covered and plastered with transparent plastic/ adhesive film. It is commonly used in the management of pressure bed sores and diabetic ulcers. It creates a suitable niche and bed for harvesting flaps. Everyday redressing of the wound is not required with this therapy. 

It acts by:

  • Reducing tissue edema
  • Clearing interstitial fluid
  • Improves perfusion and increases the healing process

questions.text: Choose the correct statement about the procedure shown in the given image.

choices.text: L1-L2 interspace is used for the procedure
Extension of the back is required for the procedure
Measurement of opening pressure can only be done in lateral recumbent position
Recumbent position following the procedure reduces the incidence of headache

questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the given image is lumbar puncture (LP). For measuring the opening pressure during lumbar puncture, the procedure must be performed in lateral recumbent position.  

Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) examination is an important step for the diagnosis of meningitis, subarachnoid hemorrhage and leptomeningeal neoplastic disease. Lumbar puncture is also used to diagnose Guillian-Barré syndrome (albumino-cytological dissociation) and to relieve the intraventricular pressure in hydrocephalus while the patient is waiting for a more definitive procedure. Relative contraindications to LP include local skin infection in the lumbar area and suspected intracranial or spinal cord mass lesion. Any bleeding diathesis should also be corrected prior to performing LP to prevent the possible occurrence of an epidural hematoma.

Either the lateral decubitus or sitting position can be used for an LP. However, measurement of opening CSF pressure can only be done in lateral decubitus. In either position, the patient should be instructed to flex the spine (option B) as much as possible. The entry site for an LP is below the level of conus medullaris, which extends to L1-L2 in most adults. Thus, either the L3-L4 or L4-L5 interspace is used as the entry site (option A). If bone is encountered during entry, the needle should be withdrawn to just below the skin and redirected more caudally.

The most common complication of lumbar puncture is post-dural puncture headache. It is a bilateral throbbing headache that increases in upright position, coughing and straining. The factors which have been shown to reduce the incidence of post-dural puncture headache are:

  • Use of atraumatic needle
  • Replacement of stylet prior to removal of needle
  • Performing LP in lateral decubitus position
  • Insertion of needle with bevel parallel to the longitudinal dural fibers

Bed rest following LP and minimizing the volume of the spinal fluid removed have not shown to reduce the incidence of post-dural puncture headache.

Related Pearl: PDPH- Post-Dural Puncture Headache

  • May follow lumbar puncture, spinal anesthesia, wet epidural tap (in which epidural needle pierced dura).
  • Onset 12-72hrs and last for 1-2 weeks.
  • Aggravated by sitting and relieved by lying down.
  • Incidence increases with the larger needle, cutting point (in comparison to pencil point) needle, young age, females, pregnancy.
  • Prevention by thinner needle

Management:

  • Supine position
  • IV fluids
  • Caffeine and analgesia
  • Epidural blood patch

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about the procedure shown in the given image?

choices.text: Patient should be asked to sit upright after the procedure
Post-procedure IV albumin has been shown to be beneficial
Lower abdominal quadrants are preferred for the procedure

questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the given image is paracentesis. Following paracentesis, the patient should be asked to lie in the supine position for a few hours. 

Paracentesis, which refers to the removal of ascitic fluid, is valuable for evaluating patients with new-onset ascites or ascites of unknown etiology. It is also indicated in patients who have a decompensation in their clinical status. Relative contraindications include bleeding diathesis, prior abdominal surgery, distended bowels, or loculated ascites. Any severe bleeding diathesis should be corrected before the procedure. Bowel distention should be relieved by placement of an NG tube, and the bladder should also be emptied before beginning the procedure.

During the procedure, the patient should be instructed to lie supine with the head end of the bed elevated. This position should be maintained for around 15 minutes so that the fluid accumulates in the dependent portion of the abdomen. The preferred entry sites for paracentesis include right or left lower quadrants of the abdomen or even a midline puncture halfway between pubic symphysis and umbilicus. To prevent leaking of the ascitic fluid, Z-tracking of the needle is helpful. The needle is advanced slowly while performing continuous aspiration. Fluid should flow freely into the syringe soon after that. For large volume paracentesis, direct drainage into large vacuum containers is commonly utilized. 

Peritoneal fluid is sent for total and differential cell count, Gram stain and bacterial cultures. Patient should be monitored following the procedure and should be asked to lie supine for a few hours. If persistent fluid leakage occurs, continued bedrest and pressure dressings are useful. For patients with decompensated liver disease undergoing large-volume paracentesis, the sudden reduction in intravascular volume can precipitate hepatorenal syndrome. Use of IV albumin in such a scenario has been shown to decrease the incidence of postprocedure renal failure.

Related Pearl: Serum Ascites Albumin Gradient (SAAG)

The serum ascites albumin gradient is calculated as follows:

SAAG = Serum albumin - Ascitic fluid albumin

It can be used to determine the cause of ascites following ascitic fluid analysis.

questions.text: An old lady slipped and fell and sustained a fracture of the upper limb. The procedure shown in the image below was used to reduce her fracture. The most likely fracture she had sustained was:
questions.solution:
The image shows traction, palmar flexion, and ulnar deviation. These steps are used in the reduction of Colle's fracture which is an extra-articular fracture of the distal radius. 

Colles' fracture occurs at the distal end of the radius, at the cortico-cancellous junction. The distal fragment shows dorsal displacement, dorsal tilt, lateral displacement and lateral tilt. This fracture is particularly common in post-menopausal women because of osteoporosis. The patient presents with pain and swelling of the wrist. On examination, there is classic dinner fork deformity.

Undisplaced Colles' fractures are managed by immobilization in a below-elbow plaster cast for 6 weeks. Displaced fractures are managed by closed manipulative reduction and immobilization in Colles' cast. The technique of reduction of Colles' fracture is as follows:

  • Disimpaction of the fracture fragments by longitudinal traction against counter traction provided by the assistant. 
  • The distal fragment is then pressed into palmar flexion followed by ulnar deviation.
  • The patient's hand is drawn into pronation, palmar flexion, and ulnar deviation.
  • A Colles' cast is then applied, extending from below the elbow to the metacarpal heads, with the wrist in palmar flexion and ulnar deviation.

Surgical correction is advisable for comminuted fractures, especially in young adults where the dominant hand is involved. It can be with percutaneous K-wire fixation, external fixators, or locking compression plates.

The most common complication following Colles' fracture is stiffness of the adjacent joints. Other complications include malunion, carpal tunnel syndrome and Sudek's osteodystrophy.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the ENT OPD with a history of pain and discharge from the right ear after accidentally inserting a button battery in that ear. Which of the following is contraindicated in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Use of alligator forceps to retrieve the button battery
Irrigation of the external auditory canal with water at 37°C
X-ray of the bilateral mastoid region
Backward traction on the pinna to better visualise the foreign body

questions.solution:
In this patient with a history of inserting a button battery in the ear, irrigation of the external auditory canal is contraindicated. 

The contraindications to irrigation of the external auditory canal include:

  • Suspected perforation of the tympanic membrane
  • Presence of a button battery in the ear
  • Unilateral deafness (when the side being irrigated is the only hearing ear)
  • Sudden onset pain or dizziness during the procedure (suggests perforation or other trauma)
  • History of prior surgery on the ear or tympanic membrane

Before the removal of a foreign body from the ear, the patient should be made to sit in a comfortable and upright position. Although it is best to not be working against gravity, some children better tolerate the procedure in a supine position. Children may also require gentle restraint on a parent's or assistant's lap. Advise the patient to remain as still as possible and to report any pain or dizziness. 

For removal of foreign bodies from the ear, alligator forceps (alternatively, straight or mosquito forceps) are required in addition to items like an otoscope, clean water, classic metal ear syringe or disposable plastic syringe, and cerumen spoon and loop. Pre-treatment with water or saline at body temperature will make the removal of the foreign body easier since it will dissolve the cerumen. However, water should not be used if the foreign body is a button battery. 

The auditory canal is straightened with gentle upward and outward traction. In children, the traction is given directly backward or even downward. Adequate visualization using the otoscope is mandatory and no instrument should be inserted blindly into the auditory canal. After successful foreign body removal, carefully examine the external auditory canal to make sure the entire object has been removed. Any inflammation or epithelial disruption on examination warrants the use of antibiotic drops.

questions.text: The following procedure can be safely performed in which of the following patients?

choices.text: Primigravida woman at 37 weeks of gestation
Primigravida woman with  amniotic fluid index (AFI) of 4 cm
Primigravida woman with premature rupture of membranes (PROM)

questions.solution:
The procedure shown above is external cephalic version. It can be safely performed in a pregnant woman at 37 weeks of gestation.

External cephalic version (ECV) is done in non-cephalic presentations like breech and transverse lie, to bring the favorable cephalic pole to the lower pole of the uterus. The ideal time to do the external cephalic version is 37 weeks. Before 37 weeks, a non-cephalic presentation has a high likelihood of correcting spontaneously and, if performed too early, attempts at version may cause a need for immediate delivery. After 37 weeks, the success rates of ECV are very low. Although it can be performed until the early stages of labor, it is not recommended.

Prerequisites for ECV include:

  • Gestational age of 37 weeks
  • Liquor should be adequate (Normal AFI of 5–25 cm) (Option B)
  • The membranes should be intact (Option C)
  • No contraindications for vaginal delivery
  • Single fetal pregnancy (Option D)

Related Pearl: External cephalic version- indications and contraindications

External cephalic version (ECV) is done to bring the favourable cephalic pole in the lower pole of the uterus.

Indications:

  • Breech presentation
  • Tranverse lie

Contraindications:

  • APH due to risk of placental separation
  • Fetal causes- hyperextension of the neck ("star-gazing" position), large fetus (>3.5 kg), congenital abnormalities, dead fetus, fetal compromise
  • Obstetric complications- severe pre-eclampsia, obesity, elderly primigravida, bad obstetric history 
  • Rh alloimmunization
  • Multiple pregnancy
  • Ruptured membrane
  • Congenital malformations of uterus
  • Abnormal CTG
  • Contracted pelvis

questions.text: Which of the following is used to inflate the bulb of the instrument given in the following image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a three-way irrigation Foley catheter. The balloon in the Foley catheter is inflated using sterile water. Use of saline is discouraged because there is a possibility of crystallization of NaCl along the balloon's lumen. If this occurs, the balloon might not deflate when the catheter is to be removed. 

Related Pearl: Foley's Catheter

A Foley catheter is a thin, sterile tube inserted into the bladder to drain urine. Because it can be left in place in the bladder for a period of time, it is also called an indwelling catheter.

French scale corresponds to the outer diameter in millimetres, and 1Fr is 0.3 mm in diameter.

Fr. size = 3 x d, where d is the outer diameter in mm. 

A 18 Fr. catheter will have a circumference of approximately 18 mm and a diameter of 6 mm.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old lady visits the Gynecology clinic for a routine check-up, during which her physician schedules a screening test for cervical cancer. Identify the correct statement about the test.
  1. Need not be deferred due to unexplained bleeding.
  2. 1 week of abstinence from intercourse is required.
  3. Ayre's spatula samples the endocervix.
  4. Cytobrush samples the ectocervix.
  5. The broom is rotated 5 times in the same direction.
questions.solution:
Statements 1 and 5 are correct regarding the screening test for cervical cancer -the Pap/ Papanicolaou test.

Before the Pap test:

  • The Pap test should not be deferred due to unexplained discharge or unscheduled bleeding as they may be signs of cervical or other genital tract cancers.
  • Ideally scheduled to avoid menstruation. It is best performed around the time of ovulation.
  • Patients should abstain from vaginal intercourse, douching, tampon use, and intravaginal medications for a minimum of 24 to 48 hours prior to the test.
  • Avoid touching the cervix before performing the Pap test, as dysplastic epithelium may get removed.
  • Ideally, confirmed cervicitis or vaginitis should be treated prior to the test

Procedure:

  • The patient is put in a dorsal position and Cusco’s self-retaining speculum is introduced.
  • The squamocolumnar junction is scraped with Ayre’s spatula completing at least one full rotation. It predominantly samples the ectocervix. 
  • Endocervix is scraped with a cytobrush, which is rotated only one-quarter to one-half turn after the ectocervix has been sampled.
  • A broom simultaneously samples both endo- and ectocervix. Five rotations in the same direction are recommended, since reversing direction may cause loss of cellular material. 
  • Samples are spread separately on 2 different glass slides and fixed using 95% ethyl alcohol.
  • Stained with Pap stain or Short stain.

The image below shows the instruments used in cervical sampling: The broom, spatula, and cytobrush in order.
